text: [Music]
[Applause]
in this video you'll see how to set up
Amazon workspaces as a product in your
ServiceNow portal when AWS service
catalog is integrated into service now
you can add workspaces to your Service
Catalog products enabling end-users to
request and receive provisioned virtual
desktops on demand
for the purposes of this demonstration
we are beginning after the initial
integration between AWS service catalog
and ServiceNow has been completed a
detailed blog on aws.amazon.com explains
how to enable this integration using the
AWS service catalog connector for
service now before we do anything else
let's quickly review how users can
request AWS products integrated into the
ServiceNow portal
users can search for what they need from
a centralized catalog of IT services
within the categories in this catalog is
AWS Service Catalog so users can request
AWS products approved by the
organization right from here
the only product made available so far
is this Amazon simple storage service or
Amazon s3 product
the end user can fill out this form to
request a provisioned s3 bucket without
having to sign into Amazon Web Services
now let's see how you can also make
Amazon workspaces available to your
end-users through service now
Amazon workspaces is a managed secure
desktop as a service solution that
enables you to provision virtual
cloud-based desktops known as workspaces
for your users if you have not already
done so you will need to configure your
AWS account to use Amazon workspaces
let's review how to do that
during setup you can configure Amazon
workspaces to authenticate users against
several different directories including
simple ad and the AWS managed Microsoft
ad you can even use the ad connector to
authenticate against an on-premises
Active Directory
for demonstration purposes we'll select
the quick setup option which uses simple
ad as the directory
by default Amazon workspaces provides
different bundles of compute capacity
operating system storage and
applications to choose from in this case
let's select a standard bundle with
Windows 10
you also need to have at least one user
in your directory in order to connect to
workspaces since this is a new directory
let's add a user now now launch
workspaces
go to the workspaces console
after a while you can refresh the view
and see that workspaces is now available
for use
you can also expand the users workspace
ID to view additional details such as
the clients download link and the
registration code the user will need to
connect to their workspace
now that you've seen how to set up
workspaces using AWS and have created a
test user in the directory let's delete
this workspace
next let's take a look at the initial
directory that was created
be sure to note the directory ID as
you'll need it for configuration later
now let's navigate to AWS Identity and
Access Management or I am to create a
new policy with permissions to launch
workspaces
choose workspaces as the service for
this policy
for the purposes of this demonstration
let's grant this policy permissions to
perform all workspaces actions your
organization can choose to grant
different permissions depending on its
own security policies and best practices
give the policy access to all resources
next provide a name and description for
the policy and then finish creating it
next navigate to roles
let's attach this policy to the role
that is used by the ServiceNow connector
to launch products in the AWS service
catalog
now that all the permissions are
configured in I am let's go to AWS
Service Catalog and create a new product
for Amazon workspaces
the products screen select the option to
upload a new product
provide some initial details about this
product
let's call this product virtual Windows
desktop
you can also enter support details for
your end-users
finally enter the version details you
can upload an Amazon cloud formation
template that defines the Amazon
workspaces product you want to make
available through ServiceNow for the
purposes of this example this template
has already been setup before proceeding
let's take a quick look at this template
as you can see these mappings make three
different Windows 10 desktop bundles
available to end-users each bundle
references the directory ID of the
directory you created earlier for user
authentication
returning to the product configuration
provide a version title and description
review the information you provide it
and then scroll down and click create
now that the product has been created
you can add it to the portfolio of
products available on ServiceNow
next create a launch constraint
keep the constraint type as launched and
then select the workspaces product from
the list
select the role that will be used to
provision resources this is the role you
added the workspaces policy to earlier
this portfolio already has a role added
with end-user access permissions so
everything in AWS has now been
configured let's navigate to ServiceNow
before you can test the new workspaces
product on ServiceNow ServiceNow must be
synced to the AWS account rather than
wait for the next scheduled sync let's
do it manually
now let's switch to the perspective of
an end-user who is looking to launch a
virtual Windows desktop in Amazon
workspaces
the user can navigate to the product
through the ServiceNow service catalog
in the AWS service catalog category the
new virtual Windows desktop item is now
available
the user just needs to fill out a brief
form to place the order
notice that the user can choose from the
three workstation types defined in the
template the user is required to provide
their windows login ID to connect to the
workspace this must be a valid username
that is already present in the directory
they can also specify any additional
tags they want associated with this
product
now they can place the order
here you can see that the request has
been automatically approved and
fulfillment has been completed if needed
ServiceNow administrators can configure
more complex workflows than this one to
require additional approvals before the
product is provisioned
returning to their ServiceNow home
screen the user now sees the workspaces
product displayed in the my AWS products
widget
they can monitor the products
provisioning which can take around 20
minutes to complete
once the product is fully provisioned
the user can use the buttons on this
page to request an update perform a
self-service action or even terminate
the workspace service now administrators
can also add the my AWS products widget
to the ServiceNow portal view with the
widget users can view details on their
AWS product requests and perform
self-service actions such as rebooting a
workspace
switching briefly to the administrator
view of the AWS management console you
can see that the users workspace was
created successfully the admin can also
manage it from here
now let's return to the end-user one
last time when the Amazon workspace has
been created the user will receive an
email with instructions on how to finish
setting up the account
once the account has been set up the
user can select a preferred method of
connecting in this case select web
access
enter the registration code provided in
the email
then type in the username and password
the user is now successfully connected
to the workspace you've just seen how to
set up Amazon workspaces as a product
and your ServiceNow portal
thanks for watching now it's your turn
to try
